item.title: UK virus deaths lowest since day after lockdown began
item.description: The government says if a vaccine trial is successful the UK will have 30 million doses by September.

item.title: Stations put crowd control measures in place
item.description: More trains begin running but rail bosses worry that social distancing will not be possible on board.

item.title: Coronavirus: Calls to investigate global response
item.description: Health leaders are to call for an independent review amid scrutiny of the WHO's handling of the crisis.

item.title: Coronavirus: European countries set to further ease lockdowns
item.description: Italy, Spain and Portugal are among the countries that will relax their restrictions from Monday.

item.title: Premier League restart to move a step closer
item.description: Premier League clubs hope to give their players the go-ahead to return to training in small groups this week.

item.title: Canadian Snowbirds acrobatic jet crashes in residential area
item.description: The Snowbirds jet was on a mission to boost the morale of Canadians fighting the spread of Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus: Brazil overtakes Spain and Italy as new cases grow
item.description: The Latin American nation now has more than 230,000 infections - the world's fourth highest number.

item.title: Probe after woman dies in Blackburn suspected shooting
item.description: She was found "unresponsive" after reports of gunshots near a supermarket, police say.

item.title: Coronavirus: Archbishop Justin Welby says austerity would be catastrophic
item.description: The Archbishop of Canterbury warns against austerity, saying it would be a "terrible mistake".

item.title: Coronavirus: Belgian hospital staff turn backs on PM Sophie Wilmès
item.description: Staff at Brussels' Saint-Pierre Hospital stage a protest during a visit by Prime Minister Sophie Wilmès.

item.title: Fed chairman Powell warns downturn 'may last until late 2021'
item.description: Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said a full rebound may not be possible until a vaccine is made.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I'm not happy going back to work. It's too soon'
item.description: Nearly 5,000 people have contacted the health and safety regulator with workplace safety concerns over the virus.

item.title: Space Plane: Mysterious US military aircraft launches
item.description: The Atlas V rocket, carrying the X-37B space plane, launched from Cape Canaveral on Sunday.

item.title: The Papers: School risk 'low' but 'are our kids safe?'
item.description: Monday's papers report new evidence the risk of coronavirus transmission in schools is "extremely low".

item.title: Coronavirus: Your pictures of working at home
item.description: Our readers reveal the new normal of life during a pandemic.

item.title: New York Governor Andrew Cuomo takes coronavirus test live on TV
item.description: Andrew Cuomo says "there is nothing about the test that should intimidate people" into not taking it.

item.title: Line of Duty team on life under lockdown
item.description: Writer Jed Mercurio and actor Vicky McClure on the show's prospects and why they made a charity promo.

item.title: One every eight minutes: India's missing children
item.description: Many of those who vanish are trafficked and exploited, but there's little public outrage.

item.title: Actor Leslie Jordan on his lockdown Instagram fame
item.description: The Emmy Award-winning star's videos have helped him to hit more than four million followers.

item.title: Eurovision 2020: Highlights from celebration show, Europe Shine A Light
item.description: Eurovision stars come together on the night that this year's cancelled contest would have taken place.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can gaming help stop lockdown loneliness?
item.description: Gamers like Millicent say their online adventures are helping them stay connected to friends in lockdown.

item.title: Coronavirus: Capturing isolation on New Zealand's Stewart Island
item.description: As the country emerges from lockdown, a photographer has documented life on rugged Stewart Island.

item.title: Eurovision: Abba's Waterloo voted best song of all time
item.description: Abba topped a BBC show's poll, before the contest's producers marked the show that might have been.

item.title: Coronavirus: The couples for whom love doesn't wait
item.description: The coronavirus outbreak may have scuppered many wedding plans, but plenty of couples are still getting engaged.

item.title: #LastNormalPhoto: Thousands share last images before lockdown
item.description: We asked you to post your last "normal" photo before coronavirus. A lot of you replied.

item.title: Inside one of Germany's 'Ghost Games'
item.description: The Bundesliga returned to action this weekend and German football writer Constantin Eckner tells BBC Sport his experience inside one of football's 'Ghost Games'.

item.title: Coronavirus doctor's diary: A super-spreading funeral that led to three deaths
item.description: Before the lockdown, many mourners at a funeral in Bradford became infected with Covid-19, and three died.

item.title: Coronavirus: Are Italians losing faith in the EU?
item.description: As Italy slowly emerges from coronavirus lockdown many citizens feel let down by the EU.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I’m scared of being buried as the wrong gender'
item.description: Some LGBT people say they feel in "more danger" than ever before.

item.title: My Money: 'No expenditure at all today!'
item.description: Bex Young from Dundee takes us through her spending in a week in her life in lockdown.

item.title: Plinofficial: Russian rapper who loved dollars arrested by FBI
item.description: A cash-flaunting rapper from Siberia came to the US to become a global star. Where did it go wrong?

item.title: Bayern Munich return to Bundesliga action with a win
item.description: Bayern Munich comfortably beat Union Berlin in another strange Bundesliga game which had the atmosphere of a training session.

item.title: Uefa has 'concrete plan' to finish European football season 'in August'
item.description: Uefa president Aleksander Cerefin says it has a "concrete plan" for finishing the season this summer.

item.title: Jordan trainers sell for record £463,000 at online auction
item.description: Basketball legend Michael Jordan's autographed trainers from 1985 sell for a record $560,000 (£463,000) in an online auction.

item.title: Arsenal taking report Lacazette inhaled nitrous oxide 'seriously'
item.description: Arsenal say they are taking a report striker Alexandre Lacazette inhaled nitrous oxide from a balloon "seriously".

item.title: Horse racing behind closed doors: How it works in Hong Kong and elsewhere
item.description: Saliva swabs, temperature checks, face masks and jockey pods have been crucial in racing continuing in Hong Kong.

item.title: Highlights: Bayern Munich re-start their season by beating Union Berlin.
item.description: Bayern Munich re-start their Bundesliga season by beating Union Berlin thanks to goals from Robert Lewandowski and Benjamin Pavard.

item.title: Borussia Dortmund beat local rivals Schalke 4-0 as football returned in Germany
item.description: Borussia Dortmund beat local rivals Schalke 4-0 in an almost empty stadium, as football returned in Germany with the resumption of the Bundesliga.

item.title: Lockdown update: All you need to know about new measures
item.description: With more restrictions eased in England on Wednesday, how will social and work life be different?

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Boris Johnson has announced changes to guidelines in England on exercise and social distancing.

item.title: Coronavirus: How will schools be able to reopen?
item.description: What do schools need to do to make sure they can provide a safe environment for pupils and staff.

item.title: Coronavirus pandemic: Tracking the global outbreak
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the respiratory virus has spread around the world and how it is being dealt with.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can you start driving lessons again? And other questions
item.description: Can you start driving lessons again? and other questions answered by BBC experts.

item.title: Coronavirus: How lockdown is being lifted across Europe
item.description: As the UK alters its restrictions, how do other European countries plan to re-open after lockdown?

item.title: Coronavirus: Who should wear a face mask or face covering?
item.description: For the first time, people in England are being advised to wear face coverings in some situations.

item.title: Coronavirus: What tests are being done in the UK?
item.description: What are the tests for coronavirus, who are they for and how do they work?

item.title: Coronavirus: How will the Covid-19 alert system work?
item.description: The threat of Covid-19 in England is to be ranked through a five-level, colour-coded alert system.

item.title: Coronavirus: How much will it cost the UK?
item.description: The pandemic will cost the government hundreds of billions of pounds. Where will it all come from?

item.title: Coronavirus: Will I be able to go on holiday?
item.description: Is it now possible to go on holiday, either in the UK or abroad?

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus lockdown: Am I allowed to move house?
item.description: The easing of lockdown will affect those who want to buy or sell a home, or rent somewhere new, in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Police across the UK now have wide-ranging powers to help fight the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: What should I do to stop the virus spreading?
item.description: Step-by-step, what to do to help prevent the spread of the virus.

item.title: How reopened schools in Denmark keep children safely apart
item.description: What's it like in a school that has re-opened? Denmark and Germany show how it might look.

item.title: Coronavirus bubbles: How do they work and who is in yours?
item.description: "Bubbles" of people we can meet safely may form part of the plans to ease lockdown in England.

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on public transport?
item.description: Bus and train operators are reducing services and increasing cleaning.

item.title: Coronavirus: Does lockdown easing 'follow the science'?
item.description: Why is England pressing ahead with plans to ease lockdown rules ahead of the rest of the UK?

item.title: Coronavirus: What does it mean if I've been furloughed by work?
item.description: Millions unable to do their job due to coronavirus will have their wages paid by a new scheme.

item.title: How do I travel to work now?
item.description: Some people are being encouraged to go back to work, but how will they get there?

item.title: How to make your own face mask
item.description: Our guide to different types of face coverings and step-by-step instructions on how to make them.

item.title: Coronavirus: Do I have to go back to work after lockdown?
item.description: With lockdown restrictions eased, people may start going back to work. But what are your rights?

item.title: Coronavirus R0: What is the R number and why does it matter?
item.description: Experts keep discussing the value of R, but what is it and why does it matter?

item.title: Coronavirus: What is the UK's test, track and trace strategy?
item.description: A guide to the three key parts of the government's coronavirus strategy after lockdowns are eased.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the new travel quarantine rules?
item.description: What do you need to know if you're planning to fly during the Covid-19 pandemic?

item.title: Coronavirus: Intensive care and other key terms explained
item.description: Use our tool to check the meaning of key words and phrases associated with the Covid-19 outbreak.

item.title: Coronavirus: Labour's Starmer says PM statement 'raises as many questions as answers'
item.description: People are being told to go back to work without clear safety guidance, Labour leader Keir Starmer says.

item.title: Joshna Maharaj - The chef who lost her sense of smell
item.description: Chef Joshna Maharaj couldn't smell for years. Now she's working to regain some of what she lost.

item.title: The faded beauty of abandoned cars across Europe and the US
item.description: Photographer Dieter Klein searched Europe and the US to discover cars lost to time.

item.title: Eurovision tribute by Fizz members and BBC correspondent
item.description: May 12 would have been the Eurovision semi-finals but the competition was cancelled due to coronavirus.

item.title: Coronavirus and Antarctica: 'Isolated within isolation'
item.description: Why the people on the only continent without a recorded case of coronavirus are in lockdown.
